title: The Mouse Who Stole Santa’s Cookie
author: Traditional

content.text: The Mouse Who Stole Santa’s Cookie  Once upon a time, in a cozy little village nestled between snowy hills, there lived a tiny brown mouse named Milo.
Milo was no ordinary mouse—he had the softest fur, the twitchiest whiskers, and a nose that could sniff out the most delicious treats from miles away.
But Milo had one big problem: he was always hungry.
One frosty Christmas Eve, as the villagers hung their stockings by the fire and children dreamed of sugarplums, Milo scurried through the quiet streets, his belly rumbling.
He had searched every pantry, every cupboard, and even the crumbs beneath the bakery’s oven, but not a single morsel had he found.
The village was too well-prepared for Christmas—every last cookie, candy cane, and gingerbread house had been tucked away for Santa’s visit.
Milo sighed, his tiny paws pressing against his empty stomach.
"If only I could find just one little treat," he whispered to the moon.
Then, as if the wind itself had heard his wish, a warm, spicy scent drifted toward him.
Milo’s nose twitched. Cinnamon. Sugar. Chocolate. His heart raced.
Following the scent, he scampered up a snow-dusted roof and peeked through a frosty window.
Inside, the room glowed with the golden light of a crackling fire.
And there, on a table covered in red velvet, sat the most magnificent cookie Milo had ever seen.
It was as big as his whole body, shaped like a jolly old man with a hat, a beard, and a belt made of icing.
A single bite had been taken from its side—Santa’s bite!—and the rest of the cookie sparkled with sugar crystals.
Milo’s eyes widened. "Santa’s cookie!" he gasped.
He had heard the stories—how Santa left treats for children all over the world, but how he also nibbled a little something himself in every home.
And here, in this very house, was the grandest nibble of all! Without thinking, Milo darted inside.
The warmth of the fire made his fur tingle, and the scent of the cookie was so strong he could almost taste it.
He climbed onto the table, his tiny claws clicking against the wood.
The cookie was even bigger up close—taller than his ears, wider than his tail! Milo licked his lips.
"Just one little bite," he promised himself. "No one will even notice."  He took a nibble. Crunch.
The cookie was perfect—sweet, buttery, with just the right amount of spice. Milo’s eyes rolled back in delight.
"Ohhh," he sighed. "One more bite." And then another. And another.
Before he knew it, half the cookie was gone! Suddenly, a deep, jolly voice boomed from the chimney.
"HO HO HO! What’s this?!"  Milo froze.
A pair of shiny black boots landed on the hearth with a thump, followed by a round belly wrapped in red velvet.
Santa Claus himself stood in the room, his rosy cheeks puffed in surprise, his white beard dusted with soot.
His eyes twinkled as he looked from the half-eaten cookie to the tiny mouse trembling on the table.
Milo’s heart pounded. He had never been so scared—or so full. "Oh dear," he squeaked.
"I—I didn’t mean to—"  Santa threw back his head and laughed, a sound like sleigh bells ringing.
"Well now, little one!
I did wonder why my cookie tasted extra special this year!" He reached into his sack and pulled out a tiny silver bell.
"I think you’ve earned this."  Milo blinked.
"A… bell?"  "Not just any bell," Santa said, tying it around Milo’s neck with a ribbon.
"This is a Christmas Mouse Bell.
Every time you ring it, a little magic will bring you a treat—just enough to fill your belly, no more, no less."  Milo’s whiskers trembled with excitement.
He gave the bell a tiny shake. Ding! A single chocolate chip appeared in his paw. Ding!
A crumb of gingerbread. Ding! A sip of warm milk in a thimble-sized cup. Santa chuckled.
"Now, how about you help me finish that cookie?" He broke off a piece and handed it to Milo, who nibbled happily.
Then Santa took a bite of his own, and together, they sat by the fire, sharing stories and laughter until the first light of Christmas morning peeked through the window.
From that day on, Milo never went hungry again.
He became the village’s official Christmas Mouse, ringing his bell whenever he needed a snack, and leaving tiny crumbs of kindness for others to find.
And every Christmas Eve, when Santa came to town, he always saved a special bite of cookie—just for his little friend.
And so, with a full belly and a heart full of joy, Milo curled up in his nest of soft hay, listening to the distant sound of sleigh bells fading into the night.
"Merry Christmas, little one," the wind seemed to whisper. And Milo, with a happy sigh, drifted off to sleep.
The End.
